preface.title: Documentation Overview
preface.para: Welcome, and thank you for using GMAT! This User GuideTraining Manual contains a wealth of material to introduce you to GMAT and how it works. It also provides an extensive Reference Guide that contains data on every Resource, Command, and major subcomponent in the system.

section.para: The chapter contains high level and introductory information on the sytem. If you need information on how to install and run the system, would like a tour of the system, want know how to configure data files, or how GMAT is organized, start here.
The section provides general information on GMAT and how to use the software.
The contains a brief project and software overview, including project status, licensing, and contributors.
The section describes how to get and install GMAT, how to run the provided samples, and where to turn for further help.
The is an in-depth guide through some of the key interface features, including the Resources tree, Mission tree, Command Summary, and Script Editor.

note.para: We consider the section to be essential reading, as it describes some fundamental aspects of how GMAT works.

section.para: The section contains in-depth tutorials that show you how to use GMAT for end-to-end analysis. The tutorials are designed to teach you how to use GMAT in the context of performing real-world analysis and are intended to take between 30 minutes and several hours to complete. Each tutorial has a difficulty level and an approximate duration listed with any prerequisites in its introduction, and are arranged in a general order of difficulty.
Here is a summary of selected Tutorials. For a complete list of tutorials see the chapter.
The tutorial is the first tutorial you should take to learn how to use GMAT to solve mission design problems. You will learn how to specify an orbit and propagate to orbit periapsis.
The tutorial shows how to use GMAT to design a Mars transfer trajectory by targeting desired B-plane conditions at Mars.
The tutorial shows how to raise orbit apogee using finite maneuver targeting.

The contains individual topics that describe each of GMAT's resources and commands. When you need detailed information on syntax or application-specific examples for specific features, go here. It also includes system-level references that describe the script language syntax, parameter listings, external interfaces, and configuration files.

The section provides general information on GMAT Resources such as Spacecraft, Propagators, Coordinate Systems, and EphemerisFiles to name just a few. Go here for details regarding syntax, options, variable ranges and data types, defaults, and expected behavior. Each section contains detailed, copy-and-paste ready examples.

The section provides general information on GMAT Commands such as Maneuver, Assignment, Optimize, and Propagate to name just a few. Go here for details regarding syntax, options, variable ranges and data types, defaults, and expected behavior. Each section contains detailed, copy-and-paste ready examples.
The section provides information on system configuration, external interfaces, the script language, and the command line interface.

note.para: This document uses two typographical conventions throughout:

listitem.para: Graphical user interface (GUI) elements and resource and command names are presented in bold.
Filenames, script examples, and user input are presented in monospace.
